markers implied by legend.</note> </base_map_notes> </continent_stats_map> <featurettes> <item> <featurette_id>eu_featurette_1</featurette_id> <title>What’s the Difference? Nations, Countries, and States in Europe</title> <body_text>Europe is home to many cultures, languages, and histories. Some groups share traditions and see themselves as one people—these are called nations. But a country or state is a place with borders, a government, and its own laws. Sometimes a nation matches perfectly with a country, and we call that a nation-state.
For example: • Scotland has its own culture and history, so we call it a “country.” But Scotland isn’t independent—it’s part of the United Kingdom. • The Basque people have their own language and traditions, but they live in parts of Spain and France without having their own separate country. • France is a nation-state, where most people share French culture, and it’s fully independent. • Russia is one country with many different nations inside it.
All over Europe, ideas about who belongs to which nation, and who controls which state, help shape identities and sometimes cause debates about independence or unity.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_1_top_left</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft1_map_scotland_uk</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>inset_map_reference</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Reference map highlighting Scotland within the United Kingdom (used as concept/reference; not clearly visible as a standalone inset on the proof).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Scotland_in_United_Kingdom.svg</final_url> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft1_map_basque_region</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>inset_map_reference</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Reference map showing the Basque region spanning Spain and France.</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a2/Basque_Country_Location_Map.svg</final_url> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft1_map_russia_ethnic_groups</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>reference_map_optional</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Reference image map of the Russian Federation by ethnic group (optional/extra; Not specified on the proof; add if desired.</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url is_null="true"/> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> </assets> <data_source_links> <item> <source_name>Wikimedia Commons / Wikipedia (reference maps)</source_name> <url is_null="true"/> <note>Specific map URLs are listed in asset hyperlinks.</note> </item> </data_source_links> <chart_spec> <item> <chart_id>eu_ft1_venn_diagram</chart_id> <chart_type>venn_diagram</chart_type> <title_on_proof>NATION / COUNTRY / NATION-STATE</title_on_proof> <layout_notes>Two-circle Venn: left labeled 'NATION (Shared Identity)', right labeled 'COUNTRY (Territory + Gov)', overlap 'NATION-STATE'. Example labels: Scotland (nation), UK (country).</layout_notes> <data_table is_null="true"/> <icon_unit_definitions is_null="true"/> </item> </chart_spec> </item> <item> <featurette_id>eu_featurette_2</featurette_id> <title>Europe’s Changing Borders—A Journey Through History</title> <body_text>The map of Europe wasn’t always as it is today. Over the last century, wars, treaties, and agreements have redrawn borders again and again. Before World War I, huge empires ruled over many peoples. After the war, these empires broke apart, and new countries appeared. After World War II, Europe split into East and West, divided by the Iron Curtain. When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, the continent began to reunite, and as the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, more new countries emerged.
Each change in Europe’s borders affected the lives of millions, sparking both struggles and opportunities. Understanding how Europe’s map evolved helps us appreciate the mix of cultures and histories across the continent today.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_2_bottom_left</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft2_map_series_borders</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>map_series_reference</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Map series showing Europe’s borders before WWI, after WWI, after WWII, and after 1991 (links point to example/reference maps).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url is_null="true"/> <url_candidates> <item>https://www.diercke.com/content/europe-world-war-one-1914-978-3-14-100790-9-36-1</item> <item>https://www.diercke.com/content/europe-countries-19201921-after-world-war-one-978-3-14-100890-6-62-2-1</item> <item>https://www.diercke.com/content/europe-countries-1949-after-world-war-two-978-3-14-100890-6-62-4-1</item> <item>https://www.diercke.com/content/europe-countries-today-978-3-14-100890-6-63-5-1?&stichwort=europe+countries</item> </url_candidates> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft2_timeline_major_events</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>timeline_graphic</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Timeline of major events in Europe (e.g., Treaty of Versailles 1919, fall of Berlin Wall 1989).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url is_null="true"/> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft2_photo_borders_placeholder</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>supporting_photo_placeholder</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Optional supporting photo (e.g., border crossing / passport stamp) to accompany the historical border-change narrative. Not on proof.</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url is_null="true"/> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> </assets> <data_source_links> <item> <source_name>Diercke World Atlas (example historical map pages)</source_name> <url is_null="true"/> <note>See asset url_candidates for specific linked pages.</note> </item> <item> <source_name>Historical atlases and government archives</source_name> <url is_null="true"/> <note>Listed in Featurettes.docx as general source category; no specific URLs provided.</note> </item> </data_source_links> <chart_spec> <item> <chart_id>eu_ft2_map_series</chart_id> <chart_type>map_series</chart_type> <title_on_proof>(no single title; shown as thumbnails)</title_on_proof> <layout_notes>Four small maps stacked vertically (proof shows sample concept thumbnails). Each map represents a different historical period (pre-WWI, post-WWI, post-WWII, post-1991).</layout_notes> <data_table> <table_ref>Europe Cultural Domain.xlsx|Changing borders featurette (historical palette tables)</table_ref> <note>Sheet contains ISO/country/HEX palettes for specific years (e.g., 1914, 1920). Confirm exact years needed vs. proof labels.</note> </data_table> <icon_unit_definitions is_null="true"/> </item> <item> <chart_id>eu_ft2_timeline</chart_id> <chart_type>timeline</chart_type> <title_on_proof>Timeline of Major Events in Europe</title_on_proof> <layout_notes>Horizontal timeline with key dates (e.g., 1919 Treaty of Versailles, 1989 fall of Berlin Wall).</layout_notes> <data_table is_null="true"/> <icon_unit_definitions is_null="true"/> </item> </chart_spec> </item> <item> <featurette_id>eu_featurette_3</featurette_id> <title>Growing Older—The Changing Faces of Eastern Europe</title> <body_text>In some parts of Eastern Europe, fewer babies are being born while people live longer. Over time, this creates an aging population, meaning there are more older people and fewer young people to work, start new businesses, or take care of those in need.
After the Soviet Union ended, many families decided to have fewer children, and some young people left their home countries for better opportunities elsewhere. This can make it harder to keep economies growing and pay for healthcare. Governments try to help by supporting families, improving healthcare, and welcoming newcomers. The story of Eastern Europe’s aging population shows how history, economics, and personal choices shape a region’s future.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_3_top_right</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft3_chart_age_distribution</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>comparative_age_distribution</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Horizontal bar chart comparing Europe’s age distribution (1920s vs 2023) across age groups (as shown on proof).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1prH68PEWb-SYjgtqtaVDaLpFSJlQp-gyPQsO-e7xC8g/edit</final_url> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft3_chart_declining_birth_rates</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>birth_rate_trend</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Chart showing declining birth rates (proof shows small-multiples style sample concept).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1GnVdVefBsYG6p9sKCbHFEmJIBaegDAG9YVo9MF5VDBE/edit</final_url> <url_candidates> <item>https://www.liveabout.com/thmb/L-mu_R4iXZmLrVO676vWZc-QLNg=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/RussianGrandmother-583f20e53df78c6f6ac8884b.jpg</item> </url_candidates> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft3_photo_aging_placeholder</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>supporting_photo_placeholder</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Optional supporting photo (e.g., multi-generational family / elders) to visually reinforce aging-population story. Final should specify which Eastern European countries and years.</layout_notes> <data_table> <table_ref>Europe Cultural Domain.xlsx|Featurettes!A3:D81</table_ref> <note>XLSX includes Russia birth/death/population table (1946–2023) labeled 'Russia birth and death rate'. Confirm if intended for this featurette or replace with regional birth-rate dataset.</note> </data_table> <icon_unit_definitions is_null="true"/> <example_reference_image>https://www.liveabout.com/thmb/L-mu_R4iXZmLrVO676vWZc-QLNg=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/RussianGrandmother-583f20e53df78c6f6ac8884b.jpg</example_reference_image> </item> </chart_spec> </item> <item> <featurette_id>eu_featurette_4</featurette_id> <title>Paris The Heartbeat of France</title> <body_text>Think of Paris as a shining star at the center of France. It’s a “primate city,” meaning it’s much bigger and more influential than any other French city. Here, fashion, art, and cuisine set trends that spread across the country and around the world. Major companies, government offices, and world-famous museums call Paris home.
Yet not everyone in France lives in this bustling capital. Many live in quiet villages or smaller towns, enjoying a slower pace of life. While Paris’s energy helps drive the nation’s economy and culture, people sometimes worry about too much focus on one city. Balancing the bright lights of Paris with the rest of France’s landscapes and traditions is an ongoing challenge.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_4_bottom_right</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft4_photo_pair_paris_vs_countryside</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>photo_pair</role> <aspect_ratio>~2:1</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo pair: Eiffel Tower (Paris) and a peaceful countryside village (France).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url is_null="true"/> <url_candidates> <item>https://media.timeout.com/images/106181719/750/562/image.jpg</item> <item>https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSLxRi9H7lFB_yPidZfc7133VN_mUzNcQsoHg&s</item> </url_candidates> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft4_map_france_paris_position</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>locator_map_reference</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Reference map of France highlighting Paris position (docx provides multiple candidate map images).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url is_null="true"/> <url_candidates> <item>https://i0.wp.com/nwegeo.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/NWEGEO-France-population-density.jpg?resize=768%2C768&ssl=1</item> <item>https://francemap360.com/img/1200/france-population-density-map.jpg.webp</item> </url_candidates> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>eu_ft4_chart_paris_population_comparison</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>bar_chart_population_comparison</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Bar chart comparing Paris population to other major French cities (Marseille, Lyon, Toulouse, Nice).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1GnVdVefBsYG6p9sKCbHFEmJIBaegDAG9YVo9MF5VDBE/edit</final_url> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> </item> </assets> <data_source_links> <item> <source_name>French census data and cultural institutions</source_name> <url is_null="true"/> <note>Listed in Featurettes.docx as general source category; <supplemental_stats_for_app> <item> <stat_id>oddball_bottled_water_italy</stat_id> <related_core_stat>Access to Clean Drinking Water</related_core_stat> <text>Italy is one of the highest per-capita consumers of bottled water globally, despite widespread access to clean tap water—reflecting cultural preferences and perceptions of taste.</text> <source>Europe Stats.docx</source> </item> <item> <stat_id>oddball_pickpocketing_barcelona</stat_id> <related_core_stat>Crime Rate (Low Crime = Safety)</related_core_stat> <text>Barcelona (Spain) is notorious for pickpocketing in crowded tourist areas (e.g., Las Ramblas) even though overall crime rates may be moderate.</text> <source>Europe Stats.docx</source> </item> <item> <stat_id>oddball_single_person_households_sweden</stat_id> <related_core_stat>Average Household Size</related_core_stat> <text>Sweden has one of the highest proportions of single-person households globally—about 50% of households consist of one person.</text>
